Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterization of the Two-dimensional/Temporal Mosaic of Drop Size Distributions and Spatial Variability (Structure) in Rain
Award.AbstractNarration:
Characteristic scales and structures of precipitation particle distributions have generally been explored over dimensions considerably larger than 1 km, yet for several reasons it is important to characterize their variability on far smaller scales. These include the need to: (1) optimize interpretation of observations made by simple rain gages and disdrometers and the translation of such measurements to much larger scales, as needed for validation of numerical weather forecasts and flood warnings; (2) better understand drop interactions and evolution in a multi-dimensional context rather than just the classical time dependent treatment in the vertical for falling precipitation (as has often been considered adequate for representation of processes including raindrop collision, coalescence and break-up); (3) achieve a more complete description of how radar-emitted microwaves interact with rain; and (4) ultimate connection and perhaps translation of 1-D observations of drop size distributions to larger 2-D domains.

The intellectual merit of this project derives from quantification of small-scale precipitation structures via combined use of a 2-D video disdrometer in conjunction with a networked array of optical disdrometers, through which investigators will calculate pair-correlation functions in rain to derive improved measures of any given precipitation field's horizontal geometry. Disdrometer observations (whose horizontal separation may be readily adjusted) will also allow examination a wide range of distances for possible scaling, self-similarity and functional structures of drop size distributions so as to better connect with remote-sensor measurements of precipitation covering large areas. The over-arching objective of this work is to collect and analyze time-series observations of rainfall over horizontal scales ranging from centimeters (as observed using a 2-D video disdrometer) up to several tens to perhaps a hundred meters or more. Broader Impacts will come through potential contributions to improved flood prediction and monitoring as well as better processes relevant to soil erosion, through support of hands-on student involvement in, and through improved observational infrastructure at an undergraduate institution serving underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to better understand the spatial and temporal structure of rain and drop size distributions on scales from centimeters to one hundred meters with extrapolation to kilometer scales if possible. Historically the scales and structures of precipitation have been explored over dimensions usually considerably larger than 1 km. Yet, it is important to characterize rain on smaller scales for several reasons. The first is that common observations by simple rain gages and disdrometers can then be translated onto much larger scales for tuning numerical weather forecasts, for the validation of rain measurements using remote sensing by radars and for use in flood warnings. This has been accomplished using the statistical properties of the rain to generate 2D rain fields consistent with the original observations but giving much wider meteorological expression to those observations so that observations by a single disdrometer can provide useful and usable validation of spaceborne and ground-based radar estimates of rainfall as well as to provide optimization of satellite communication approaches in the tropics. An understanding on 1km and smaller scales is also important for other reasons ranging from improving flash flood warnings and for developing better soil erosion controls.

From a purely scientific perspective, there is still much to be learned about the formation and evolution of rain. Current understanding is based upon one spatial dimensional (1D)-time dependent treatment in the vertical. Yet, a full understanding of drop evolution requires understanding drop interactions and evolution all three spatial dimensions in addition to time. This evolution is important because it impacts how how microwaves interact with rain which determines how accurately radars can be used to estimate rainfall in storm and flood warnings, for example. As a first step it is necessary to provide descriptions of 2D structures for later incorporation into multi-dimensional simulations of rain formation. This research provided the first reported estimates of the statistical two dimensional characterizations of rain and drop size distributions on scales less than 100 m down to 10 cm scales.

On a related topic, the radar estimation of rainfall is based upon drop sizes and numbers. For historical reasons, however, over the last 70 years the research into the connection between what radars measure and the rainfall rate has focused on measuring drop sizes with little concern for the number of drops. This study showed that the reason for this is that for single instruments, the rainfall rate and its variability is most highly correlated to the variability of the  drop. In reality, once the observation domain increases to be on the order of 1 or more kilometers, the dependence of rainfall rate on the distribution of drop sizes loses its importance. Instead the rainfall rate and its variability depend only on the number of drops although one still needs to know an average drop size. This is a much easier variable to estimate. Thus, there is no longer any need to obsess over obtaining detailed drop size observations over large areas, essentially impossible to ever achieve anyway.

The outcomes from this project are:

  • A method was developed to extract more of the information contained in the time series of drop counts in rain which can then be expressed over large 2D areas for use in radar-rainfall rate validations and other studies.
  • It was shown that the rainfall rate is much more strongly correlated to the total number of drops than to the mean drop size
  • Network observations revealed signi?cant differences between spatial and temporal structures suggesting that temporal observations of clustering cannot be used to infer spatial and that temporal fluctuations occur independently of spatial fluctuations
  • It was also shown that there is a linear relation between 1-min averages of the rainfall rate R over the network and the average total number of drops N. Temporal and spatial size distributions and their variabilities are not equivalent.
  • The DSD is the product of the total number of drops N times the probability size distributions (PSDs). The average PSD fails to characterize its true variability over an area. This variability of the PSD increases with the expansion of the network size and with increasing drop diameter with a saturation level in the variability occurring for dimensions larger than around 1 km.
  • While the importance of PSDs looms large for small domains used in past studies, over domains larger than around 1 km, it is the variability of the total number of drops that dominates the variability of R regardless of the PSD.
